Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Model-based Energy Management for Sustainable Buildings

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Modern society depends on a massive amount of, largely ?dirty,? energy to sustain itself. Collectively, buildings consume more energy than the other broad sectors of consumption. A significant barrier to improving building energy efficiency is that fine-grained monitoring of electrical loads at large scales remains impractical: it is expensive, invasive, and unreliable. Our hypothesis is that a comprehensive repository of detailed models that describe how loads use power provides a foundation for programmatically managing building energy consumption. The project?s goal is to advance research and education using the model-based paradigm to design automated load discovery, monitoring, and scheduling techniques that are low in cost, highly transparent, and privacy preserving. To achieve this goal, the project will bootstrap and seed an online data repository to enable new techniques for modeling loads based on their energy usage. Since many types of loads exist, our goal is to develop a library of load modeling techniques. The project will then leverage these models to automatically discover the set of loads a building operates, and monitor their electricity usage using only aggregate electricity recorded by a building smart meter. To benefit students, the project will develop new courses on building energy management, and make the materials publicly available to benefit educators. Importantly, the courses will enable students to gain hands-on experience by ?programming? real buildings. This learning-by-doing approach is highly effective---simply turning devices on and off via computer is eye-opening---and will serve as a catalyst for including undergraduates in research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Modern society depends on a massive amount of, largely "dirty," energy to sustain itself. Collectively, buildings consume more energy than all other broad sectors of consumption. A significant barrier to improving building energy efficiency is that fine-grained monitoring of electrical loads at large scales remains impractical: it is expensive, invasive, and unreliable. To address the problem, this project developed a new "model based" approach capable of analyzing data from a single building-wide electricity meter to extract useful information from it in real time, rather than deploying numerous individual meters.  This information may include per-device electricity usage, occupancy, location, and solar generation.  Since such "smart" building-wide electricity meters are widely installed in buildings throughout the United States, there is a large potential to extract useful information from them that can improve the energy-efficiency of buildings and the electric grid. The project's model-based approach was novel in that it integrated fundamental physical models of electric load behavior to enable high accuracy with empirical data-driven models to enable high scalability. The project developed a number of data analytics techniques for extracting useful information from building smart meter data, including occupancy monitoring, virtual plug meters, and solar disaggregation. The project also developed ways to use this information at large scales to enable more efficient building energy management, e.g., automatically adjusting a thermostat based on learned occupancy status.  The project employed an empirical systems-driven methodology that deeply instrumented real buildings with sensors to collect data and gathered data from existing deployments for evaluation. 


Broader impacts of the project included the public release of large-scale energy datasets and energy analytics software for use by the research community.  The project also supported the development of a novel Green Computing course that focuses on leveraging computation, networking, and sensing to improve the energy-efficiency of society, e.g., by automatically regulating energy consumption in buildings, homes, the electric grid, etc. This course is part of a new Internet-of-Things (IoT) graduate certificate program. The project also supported undergraduate summer research projects, as well as lectures on Green Computing for a high school summer program for students interested in engineering.  One doctoral student supported through this award took up a tenure-track faculty position after graduation.  The project supported two summer REU students, one of whom co-authored a paper and recently graduated and is now pursuing a Ph.D.
